solution_line_template: First, we need to find the amount Matt read both years to establish what Pete read, so to find Matt's first-year total we multiply {matt_second_year_books} / {matt_increase_factor} = <<{matt_second_year_books}/{matt_increase_factor}={matt_first_year_books}>>{matt_first_year_books} books the previous year.

Since Pete read twice as many books as Matt did in the first year, and Matt's first-year total is {matt_first_year_books}, this means Pete read {matt_first_year_books}*{pete_first_year_multiplier}=<<{matt_first_year_books}*{pete_first_year_multiplier}={pete_first_year_books}>>{pete_first_year_books} books his first year.

Since Pete doubled the number of books he read the following year, this means Pete read {pete_first_year_books}*{pete_second_year_multiplier}=<<{pete_first_year_books}*{pete_second_year_multiplier}={pete_second_year_books}>>{pete_second_year_books} books the following year.

We add the two years of Pete's reading together to find {pete_second_year_books}+{pete_first_year_books}=<<{pete_second_year_books}+{pete_first_year_books}={total_pete_books}>>{total_pete_books} books read in total.
